author: (Say, 1831)
notes: An operculate snail with sessile eyes.

author: (Muller, 1774)
notes: Glossy.

author: (Doherty, 1878)
notes: Glossy.

author: (Say, 1816)
notes: Globose to moderately depressed.

author: (Deshayes, 1830)
notes: Widest umbilicus of any Discus (except bryanti).

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Irregularly striate. Sometimes has fine spiral lines. Glossy.

author: (Muller, 1774)
notes: Sometimes shell has no visible shell navel (umbilicus) and the apertural whorl shows a slight blunt keel.

author: (Dall, 1888)
notes: Spiral striae start at apex. Weak growth wrinkles.

author: (Say, 1817)
notes: Spiral striae missing or weak from first 1.5 whorls.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Last whorl has thread-like striae, and close impressed spiral lines often punctate in places. Short callus or low tooth in basal margin.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Umblicus is always only partially covered.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Embryonic whorl has smooth tip, then finely striate.

author: (Say, 1816)
notes: Usually has parietal tooth, but may be absent.

author: (A. Binney, 1837)
notes: Parietal tooth usually present, but may be absent.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: The flattened shell of Patera appressa is decorated with coarse, radial striae beginning at the second whorl, and some scattered, microscopic papillae. Fine striae on the inner whorls are spaced at wide intervals. The shell comes to a sharp angle at the front periphery, but is less acute at the back. The aperture is wide and rounded, with a broad lip and a sharp rim inside the basal part of the opening. The umbilicus is covered.

author: (Pilsbry, 1940)
notes: Papillae are microscopic and form spiral lines towards the end of upper surface of the last whorl.

author: (Green, 1827)
notes: First half whorl smooth, next half whorl closely striate below suture.

author: (G.H. Clapp, 1904)
notes: Stiff hairs about 0.5mm in length, widely spaced, cross the lines of growth at nearly a right angle. Width of the mouth is 1mm-- double S. stenotrema.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Usually without parietal tooth. Sometimes without color bands. Rather glossy. First 1.5 whorls smooth, then fine oblique striae with weakly spiral engraved lines in their intervals.

author: (F.C. Baker, 1921)
notes: Aperture: oval, lunate; parietal lamella long, curved, narrowly separated or attached to axial callus, outer lip with a low lamella, often missing; basal lip with a thickened ridge forming a low lamella; peristome reflected, thickened within, channeled behind; parietal callus thin and translucent, leading edge “S”-shaped, wrapping around axial callus. Surface: rather dull; embryonic whorls with fine axial lines, portions smooth; later whorls with prominent axial ridges; spiral lines very fine, less distinct on base. Color: light yellowish brown, brighter yellow behind lip; lip white.

author: (Say, 1824)
notes: Parietal tooth turned to thickened basal lp.

author: (A. Binney, 1841)
notes: The entire profile of this may be wrong. Need more research.

author: (I. Lea, 1841)
notes: First 1 1/2 whorls are smooth, then has closely spaced ribs and spiral striae

author: (H.B. Baker, 1930)
notes: First whorl irregularly wrinkled. Last 3/4 embryonic whorl spiral striae become more distinct.

author: (Say, 1822)
notes: Ovate-conic. Aperture almost closed by teeth.

author: (Say, 1816)
notes: Transverse Striae weak. Only 2 teeth.

author: (Say, 1822)
notes: Typically 5 teeth.

author: (C.B. Adams, 1842)
notes: Eight teeth

author: (E.S. Morse, 1865)
notes: Cylindrical ovate. Weak striae. Five teeth.

author: (A. Binney, 1843)
notes: Usually 5, sometimes 4, teeth.

author: (Gould, 1840)
notes: Six teeth.

author: (Draparnaud, 1801)
notes: Weak striation.

author: Wolf, 1870
notes: Shell is honey yellow. Mostly with 3 teeth.

author: (E.S. Morse, 1865)
notes: Granules or puncta only seen under high magnification. Five teeth.

author: (Gould, 1840)
notes: Transverse striae under magnification.

author: Pilsbry, 1926
notes: Narrowly umbilicate (diameter is 6 1/2x umbilicus).

author: (Say, 1817)
notes: Narrowly umbilicate (contained 9 to 11 times in diameter).

author: (Say, 1817)
notes: Spire is smaller than aperture. Genital aperture noticably swollen.

author: (I. Lea, 1834)
notes: Oxyloma have spires smaller than aperture opening. Aperture is narrowly ovate.

author: (Say, 1829)
notes: Catinella species have spires almost as long as aperture.

author: Sterki, 1893
notes: Surface: of embryonic whorls smooth, later whorls with prominent axial ribs and smaller irregular lines in between; body whorl with about 30 to 38 ribs. Color: grayish white, translucent; peristome similarly colored.

author: Sterki, 1893
notes: Surface: of embryonic whorls smooth, finely granulose; later whorls with prominent axial ribs,and fine irregular growth lines in between; body whorl with about 35 ribs. Color: grayish white, translucent.

author: (Say, 1823)
notes:
Indented transverse striae-- usually about 28. Umbilicus contained 25 to 30 times in diameter. Spiral striae fine.
Surface: glossy, embryonic whorl finely granulose; later whorls with regularly spaced axial grooves, about 28 on body whorl, extending across the base to the umbilicus; spiral striae faint, but may usually be seen on some parts of the body whorl. Color: light amber, translucent to nearly transparent. Animal: bluish black.

author: (A. Binney, 1841)
notes:
Umbilicus about 3 times in diameter. Embryonic whorl smooth, then unevenly striate above, smooth below. Transverse striae are under magnification, and spiral striae are faint.
Surface: of embryonic whorl smooth; later whorls with fine uneven growth lines; spiral striae faint or not visible. Color: grayish white with faint brownish cast, translucent. Animal: bluish black.

author: (Say, 1821)
notes: Papillae are closely arranged almost in a spiral striae.

author: (E.S. Morse, 1864)
notes: Separated from N. electrina by being smaller, its shell is white with greenish tint. Animal dark blue.

author: (Gould, 1841)
notes:
Shell transparent with a faint yellow or green tint. Very dark animal.
Surface: glossy, first whorl smooth, later whorls with irregularly spaced axial grooves, base with grooves greatly diminished, spiral striae fine to absent. Color: light brown with a yellowish or greenish tint, translucent. Animal: almost black, lighter near the foot; sole tripartite, separated by impressed lines.

Umbilicus 6 times in diameter. Shell clear corneous with a faint amber or yellowish above, and whitish around umbilicus. Animal light gray, darker above, pale sole, and brown spots at mantle. 
urface: glossy, embryonic whorls smooth, later whorls with axial growth lines barely visible; spiral striae faint. Color: light yellowish brown, underside whitish. Animal: usually pale bluish gray.

author: (Stimpson, 1850)
notes: Ribs start after first 1.5 whorls. Umbilicus 1/3 width of body. The shell of Striatura exigua is uniquely sculptured, with fine spiral lirae creating a crosshatch pattern interrupted by taller transverse ridges. No other tiny shell bears this one-of-a-kind microsculpture. The umbilicus is open and wider than the aperture, which is rounded and simple.

author: (E.S. Morse, 1859)
notes: The tiny shell of Striatura milium has a depressed heliciform shape, is more loosely coiled and has a little bit coarser microsculpture than other Striatura species. Compared with other striates, it lacks sculpture on its nuclear whorl. The tops of the remaining whorls are ribbed radially, with intersecting spiral lirae. The base is nearly smooth. The umbilicus is open and the rounded aperture is angled slightly downward.

author: (Say, 1816)
notes:
Surface: of embryonic whorls smooth; later whorls
with weak axial growth lines and minute spiral striae. Color: light yellowish brown with olive tint, translucent, glossy. Animal: bluish gray, lighter on the sides; tail unpigmented; eyes black; sole white or light gray.

author: (A. Binney, 1840)
notes:
This species may be confused with Discus whitneyi, but is distinguished by the axial ridges, which in D. whitneyi are much coarser and more regularly spaced, with the ridges well defined on the base.
Surface: of embryonic whorls smooth; later whorls with close spaced, prominent axial ridges, which are less distinct on the ventral surface.
Color: whitish corneous, some with a greenish tint; translucent to opaque.

author: (Muller, 1774)
notes: Animal is black. Small orange spot behind shell near opening.
